div.p: Greetings. I am still engaged in my labors; therefore, I will be brief.
We are doing quite well here by the grace of God; I hope you are also in good health. Your letters have been delivered to me in good faith.
I thank you for your diligence.
I have nothing at present worthy of you.

I leave it to your discretion whether to accept Augustine or not. I believe Mr. Gessner is occasionally gifted with manuscripts by friends, and our law among other things states that a good lord or friend, as has always been the custom, may take from his own goods and give gifts without danger. However, I have never wanted to accept anything of any significance from the envoys of kings. I gave several books to Cognetius; he sent me Theophylact on the 4 Gospels; I, in turn, sent him others to repay him, etc. I can hardly believe that Philip of Spain will allow the Pope to use Milan at his own discretion. Ferdinand and Philip do not agree well because of Milan.

Perhaps the cardinals will order this pope to die. I have long since handed over the miserable horse to you, dead and alive, boiled and roasted; take what you can, I want nothing of it here; the crows may carry it away on the road. What you take is gain; for I am always worried that, in addition to all costs, I must also pay the executioner's fee. Therefore, sell it as you can and as if it were your own.

My son Stoffel has always been fond of horses and riding; God has placed him on a miserable donkey, if he would become wise, it would be a good little horse. But joking aside; I give you full power to sell, etc.
I will always show myself grateful to you.
Pay the price to the smith; I will repay everything in good faith.
Farewell and greet Mr. Philipp, Pontasella, the consuls, the envoy, and all friends.
To the most excellent man Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the Church of Chur, his most esteemed and beloved lord and brother. Chur.
